userreviews.userReview: In this 9th book in the 'Sarah Booth Delaney' series, the private detective investigates the cause of a mysterious illness in her home town. It's best to read the books in order, but the mystery can be read as a standalone.*****Hollywood actress and private detective Sarah Booth Delaney hurries back to her home town of Zinnia, Mississippi when a mysterious disease breaks out there. Several people, including Oscar - the husband of Sarah Booth's best friend and detective partner Tinkie Richmond - are in the hospital, seriously ill. All the patients got sick after visiting Zinnia's run-down Carlisle Plantation. Each human victim experienced a burning fever and delirium before falling into a deathlike coma. The cause of the sickness is unknown, though it seems to be connected to the plantation's bioengineered cultivar. The Carlisle Plantation, which is no longer a profitable working concern, is being used to grow an experimental cotton crop that - in addition to being plagued by boll weevils - may harbor some unidentified infectious agent. The Carlisle estate is a source of contention between its two co-owners, brother and sister Luther and Erin Carlisle. Luther wants to sell the land to developers, while Erin wants to keep it in the family. Either way, the 'disease situation' may affect the plantation's future.The doctors in Zinnia do everything they can to treat the comatose patients, to no avail. Thus the Centers for Disease Control (CDC) sends two Ph.D. scientists to help. One of them - a gorgeous blonde named Bonnie Louise - immediately gloms onto Sarah Booth's ex-boyfriend, Sheriff Coleman Peters. Sarah Booth, who's dating a Hollywood actor, tells herself she doesn't care.....but she seems very concerned. 😑Though two trained scientists are now on the scene, Sarah Booth insists on investigating herself. The detective is determined to find out what's causing the disease, so she can save Oscar's life. (In real life, this would be ludicrous. Highly trained doctors and scientists can take years to identify the cause of a new disease. An amateur - who isn't even a biologist or physician - wouldn't have a chance. 😏) In any case, Sarah Booth's other best friend - the fashionable transgender journalist Cece Dee Falcon - also offers to make inquiries. Sarah Booth's and Cece's interference leads to serious problems for both women. As all this is going on, Sarah Booth gets regular visits from her personal ghost Jitty, who haunts Sarah Booth's ancestral home, Dahlia House. Jitty is always changing her outfits, which is fun. She's also constantly pushing Sarah Booth to have a baby, which gets old. After considerable drama and trauma, everything is discovered in a climax I didn't predict.This is an enjoyable addition to the series, recommended to fans of cozy mysteries. You can follow my reviews at https://reviewsbybarbsaffer.blogspot....

Carolyn Haines has been called the “Queen of Cozies” and the ninth release in her Sarah Booth Delaney series (Greedy Bones, Minotaur, July, 2009) is as fresh and vibrant as the first. The “ghost” in the series isn’t a detective, but she’s an intriguing character named Jitty, who pops up to offer words of advice and solace to the main character, Sarah Booth. (But only if she feels like it, of course.)Jitty, the resident haint of Dahlia House, gives new meaning to the word “feisty.” She’s fun, fearless, totally unpredictable and most importantly, she cannot be summoned at will. When she does pop up, usually wearing an outrageous costume, she invariably says something that’s both witty and perceptive. Sometimes her comments ”drive too close to home,” as Sarah Booth ruefully admits and Jitty has a way of getting to the heart of the matter.This delightful series is set in Zinnia, Mississippi, but the eighth release, (Wishbones, Minotaur, June 2008 ) takes place in Costa Rica. A film company is doing a remake of Body Heat and Sarah Booth finds herself caught up in a murder mystery (as well as a romantic liaison.) The dialogue is crisp and lively and the description of the movie set is spot on.Ham Bones (Southern Belle Mysteries, Minotaur) June 2008, is another winner. When the New York cast of Cat on a Hot Tin Roof comes to Zinnia, Sarah Booth finds herself once again involved in a murder investigation, with the trusty Jitty providing ghostly guidance and support.Why are ghostly mysteries so popular? As Gail Link, romance writer (LUCK OF THE DRAW, Dorchester, 2006) and bookseller states, “These books have timeless qualities of love, loss and redemption. The ghostly detective is there to help, or work though something that was left unfinished on earth." For mysteries that have captivating characters, compelling plots and a touch of the supernatural, you won't want to miss this terrific series by Carolyn Haines.

Sara Booth Delaney and Tinkie Richmond are back in Zinnia, Mississippi where Tinkie's husband Oscar has succumbed to a plague-like illness that has even the U.S. Center for Disease Control and Prevention stumped. Tinkie is afraid to leave Oscar's bedside. Sara Booth is on her own as she searches for clues that will help diagnosis this life threatening illness. Meanwhile, the number of victims increases.All the patients have in common is a visit to the Carlisle cotton plantation run by Agri-Team, a farming consortium. The cotton there is two feet tall while the rest of Sunflower County cotton is barely breaking ground. The Carlisle heirs are at odds about whether to sell the plantation to a land developer. Each accuses the other of prior bad acts, including murder.How does an unproven murder at the Carlisle Plantation fit in with an unknown illness, genetically altered cotton, and mutated boil weevils? Haines' twisty plot will keep you guessing until the end. Readers will also be surprised at the changes in Sara Booth's private life.

Sarah Booth has returned to Zinnia, Mississippi because the husband(Oscar) of her best friend and partner, Tinkie is dying and no one knows from what or how to cure him. Tinkie asks Sarah Booth to find out what is happening so Oscar can be saved. The case involves disease both to humans and to a cotton crop. It also involves murder but the motives are murky with side issues blurring the real villain. The book was a quick easy read.

I have loved all the others in the series but this one had a little something more for me. I thought the plot was really interesting, the details, etc. I also thought I had figured out the whodunit but there was a suprise twist. Not sure why this book was different, maybe because it seemed like Sarah Boothe's life is changing for the best, finally. Nonetheless, I couldn't put it down.
Genetically modifying bol weevils and causing a CDC epidemic? Stretches credibility a bit. Then Sarah Booth is married to Hollywood hunk Graf Milieu. Add this one to the ridiculous pile.
A great for-fun read....
She got me. The murderer and reason for it all was a total surprise. I love to spoil it for you but that is wrong.

Maybe I've read too many in this series but I didn't like this one as much. I got the feeling it flew off the keyboard and into the printing plant without an editor. What do editors do these days if they aren't actually editing books? This one has a lack of continuity-for instance, when Sarah Booth decides to go for a ride in the middle of the night, she "whistles up her hound" to go along, but the dog is never mentioned as accompanying her. Logic also is missing here-in her zeal to find out the cause of a deadly illness that's struck her best friend Tinkie's husband and three others, she goes without food and without sleep for days, and only once did she feed her horses and the dogs. I guess the author figured we'd be too busy figuring out who the dastardly criminal is to pay attention to little details like that. And lots of details are ignored in the mad dash to Find Out What's Going On.I'd think that experts from the Centers for Disease Control would be doctors-if not medical, then at least Ph.Ds, and the ones sent to Sunflower County are addressed as Ms. and Mr.. I had a very hard time believing that anyone who just survived a severe beating and a miscarriage (sorry if this is a spoiler for you but anyone could see that one coming a mile away), while having gone without food and sleep for days, would still have the strength to get out of a hospital bed and meet with a killer in an abandoned building without backup. It was a little too cartoonish for my taste. Sarah Booth has evolved into some kind of superhero P.I. who doesn't even have a P.I.'s license, yet she continues to ignore pleas to wait for the police, and rush headlong into the kind of situations where she could get herself and her friends killed. I just realized that I don't know what became of Bonnie Louise, and I don't care enough to pick the book back up and find out whether or not the author forgot to mention that little detail. Another problem I have with the series is the timeline-she keeps referring to the 18 months since she came back to Sunflower County, and in that time has had more than a half-dozen cases. Setting aside the idea that a sleepy little county in Mississippi could possibly have so many murderers and mysteries, that's an awful lot of exhausting cases in eighteen months. Most people don't even have the kind of adventures Sarah Booth has in their lifetimes. Then again, maybe that's part of the appeal-let a plucky heroine with a strange "Delaney womb" have the adventures for you while you read about it. I'm reading one more title that I got from the library, and after that I'm going to take a vacation from Sarah Booth for a while and see if it's my crankiness getting to me, or if my gripes about the books are right.

I didn't set out to read this entire book yesterday, and yet I did. And I'm thinking of going to find another book in the series. I enjoyed the tone and characters in the book. I definitely think I'd like to read another one because this story line has the usual partners split up and the book is mostly Sarah Booth on her own (which I gather isn't the norm). It's hard to really judge the supporting characters based on this book alone. But that I want to read another one, that's a good sign.I did have one problem with this story though. I appreciate that there were a lot of "who dunnit" twists and turns at the end of the book (though, maybe one too many?) designed to keep you on your toes. I definitely never put the exact partnership of evil doers together myself. But here's the problem, while I didn't solve the mystery, it reads like that happened because the author hadn't either. Like maybe she just pulled two names out of the hat at the end of the book and Ta Da they did it. She definitely didn't explain the whys and hows of the final duo very well.There were too many coincidences that ALL the people involved had fabulous motivation to commit the crime but the ones who did it... didn't? What did they really hope to get out of this? How did they amass such a perfect team to lay the blame on? Could all the other characters' motivations really been at play and yet this is who did it? Just... we were left with too many questions after all this. And of course, the character I most want to have explain her why can't do so in the end. So that sucks.If what you are looking for a is a cozy book that reads like a light romp and distraction then this might work for you. (Despite the far from light subjects in it.) But if what you want is an actual mystery then this isn't the book to read.

This mystery is about an independent ad stubborn Mississippi gal Sarah Booth Delaney that has a detective agency with her best friend and partner, Tinkie. In their line of work, they comes across a lot of danger. Even though I read the next book, Bone Appetite in this series I am glad I read this book. This story starts with Sarah Booth's husband, Oscar sick with an illness that the CDC can't even explain. There are 3 others in the same dilemma. From a previous near death case, Sarah Booth has a short lived Hollywood career and a movie star boyfriend, named Graf. As she works on the case, there is a glimpse of men in her town of Zinnia and past romances with them, especially the sheriff, Coleman.Her friends support her as her boyfriend is in California filming a movie. Her resident ghost, Jitty is there to give her advice as well. As she starts to investigate, the Carlisle House where the trouble began she finds out that the Carlisle family has a lot of tragic circumstances that may have led to death and greed. There are several suspects throughout the book and Sarah is close to death. Lots of turns through this mystery.

GREAT GREAT Book! There are so few series authors that I can count on to deliver; Carolyn Haines and her Southern Mississippi characters always come through for me. Each novel gets better and better, this is one of my favorites! I always save these up for in between less good novels…Sarah Booth’s world is caving in and she will have to think fast in order to save herself and her friends. Tinkie’s husband is in the hospital, dying of a mysterious disease. Tinkie is beside herself, never leaving Oscar’s side. Sarah Booth promises Tinkie that she will investigate the cause of Oscar’s illness. When the ever brave CeeCee goes to assist in the investigation, she ends up in the hospital. Sheriff Coleman might assist Sarah but they will have to figure out how or if they can move forward. Coleman is getting a divorce, but Sarah is now dating Graff—the handsome wonderful movie star…Sarah will fight to stay alive, to keep Oscar alive and must quickly work to figure out just who is behind the mysterious disease and other murders that occur throughout the investigation.

Good Mystery...........not one I would want to read when I needed something light and humourous.Most of the characters were likeable and intelligent women that interacted very sweetly/ well with each other.Some sad events in the story but that kept it more true to life. Good plot and my guess at the who in whodunit kept changing every few chapters. Ending...thumbs up. A tale of very strong friendships and the love relationships kept my heart divided between two.The relationship between Tinkie and her husband is so touching and the drama that they go through left tears in my eyes. I really liked the southern venue. Very discriptive and true to life. I also liked the fiesty southern women. They took matters into their own hands , not waiting around, wringing their hands waiting for a man to come on a white horse and save them . And I want a Jitty of my own.

This was actually better than I thought it would be.... I do like the series but this started off with such sadness, that I almost gave up, I'm glad I didn't.Tinkie's husband Oscar and 3 other people have been out to an abandoned plantationthat is growing G.M. cotton which is being eaten by G.M. weevils, all four are now in ICU and fighting for their lives.....no one can figure out what is going on.Sarah Booth Delaney wants to get to the bottom of the illness but along the way stumbles upon: a greedy heir trying to force his sister to sell the plantation, the mysterious deaths of their parents, an illegitimate sister of the heirs, a bogus land developer, and a former resident turned Disease Control Agent who is hot on Sarah Booth's former flame Sheriff Coleman.... And let us not forget Sarah Booth's haint: Jitty!

Great way to end the year, with another Sarah Booth Delaney mystery. This time I felt like we really got to see a side of Sarah Booth's personality that we normally don't get to see, that of a still grieving daughter. Yes, it has been touched upon, but in this book her feelings are brought more to the surface. This, with the help of supporting characters Jitty and Tammy. Again, true friendship is the thread that holds all of the characters together and the sense of feeling "at home". The mystery was interesting and I was again glad I had not guessed who the culprit was. I love thinking I know the "who done it part" and flip flopping between the evil doers. All reasons why this is one of my favorites series and why I keep coming back for more~

This book really showcased the friendship between Sarah Booth and Tinkie. It also showed how in the small amount of time that she has been back Sarah Booth has really found her place in the town and among the townspeople. I wish things had worked out with her and Coleman because I would like to see her stick around, and I don't think that will happen with Graf. For some reason I just don't like him. The twists and turns about the cotton and the weevils just kept coming. Some of them I had figured out, but others surprised me. I had figured out what was happening to Sarah Booth right away and was heartbroken to see what happened to her. It will be interesting to see how things play out in the next book.

Since I don't normally write reviews unless I have something specific to say, here's the break down of how I rate my books...1 star... This book was bad, so bad I may have given up and skipped to the end. I will avoid this author like the plague in the future.2 stars... This book was not very good, and I won't be reading any more from the author.3 stars... This book was ok, but I won't go out of my way to read more, But if I find another book by the author for under a dollar I'd pick it up.4 stars... I really enjoyed this book and will definitely be on the look out to pick up more from the series/author.5 stars... I loved this book! It has earned a permanent home in my collection and I'll be picking up the rest of the series and other books from the author ASAP.

Sarah Booth Delaney returns home to Mississippi to support her best friend and partner, Tinkie. Tinkie's husband and 3 other people are suffering from an unknown disease that is slowly killing them. The only link is that they all visited a local plantation. Sarah Booth is convinced that the mysterious cotton crop and boll weevils that have appeared on the plantation are not an accidient of nature. She smells foul play and determined to get to the root of the mystery.I love this series. The characters continue to develop and the mysteries continue to improve. This one was a tricky one. Just when I thought I knew what was going on, another clue would pop up. I recommend reading this in series to get full enjoyment of the series.

These book just keep up the drama. I was not sure how the whole Sarah/Coleman relationship would be now that Sarah is with Graf but that seemed to be ok. I found the mystery in the book to be good. Having said that this book turns dark fast. I had the blurb on the next book and notice a certain event wasn't mentions so with that in mind I knew there was going to something very bad that happened to Sarah. so with that in mind I wasn't surprised when it happen, n=but it did pull the book into a much darker place.Overall it was an ok read Sarah just takes some really hard knocks in this book. It seems like she can never have it all ,

50 States and at least 50 Authors 2016 Reading Challenge. MISSISSIPPI.Tinkie's husband Oscar is dying along with three others and the only thing they have in common is that they all visited the Carlisle Plantation. Is it an infection by bacteria or viruses or is it a chemical poisoning? Was it accidental or deliberate? Who is behind this and what can be done to save the four patients? Doc is stumped. The CDC is called in to help. Does this have anything to do with the history of the Carlisle family? Was the mother's death accidental or murder? Was the father's death suicide or murder? Is their son responsible? So very many questions and Jitty is acting weird.

For about half the book I wasn't too sure how much I liked the book. The Southern way of life isn't that familiar making me feel like an outsider. The book draws the reader in a bit at a time. By the half way point I felt comfortable and began to enjoy the ride.It seems four people went out to an old plantation house and cotton fields. They ended up deathly ill in ICU on life support. Why? Why didn't anyone else get sick?The story twists and turns. The motive is revenge, but whose and for what? It isn't clear until near the end of the book.The book goes fast and is a fun read.

I read this for the OSC bookclub a few weeks ago. I enjoyed the Southern setting, but didn’t find the characters very engaging or the plot line believable. I guess it would be ok for a light mystery beach read, but would recommend The Rock Orchard: A Novel or The Wilde Women: A Novel for better reads.

Some of Sarah Booth's friends are dying of a mysterious disease. She works with the sheriff, her former love, and investigators from the Centers for Disease Control, one of whom has her eye on the sheriff. The disease seems to be related to a tragic old plantation, or to the genetically-altered cotton growing there, or to the boll weevils that seem to be also genetically designed to feed on the cotton. Sarah Booth investigates the family that owns the plantation, as well as the shady developer who wants to build on it.

This one seems to be a little on the weird side. I thought having everyone going around falling all over themselves for the "Daddy's girl" phenomena was bad, but the boll weevil was not only oh too obvious a twist, it also did not make sense biologically.However, the details were well done, even if the characters appear to bright but clueless. I enjoy this unusual look at the south, and although I did not like this story much, at least Sarah Booth is moving out of the pathetic child stage. Now if she could only grow up...

Carolyn Haines has created a wonderful town called Zinnia, Mississippi where a cast of characters lives. If you are looking for a good mystery with interesting people, any of Carolyn Haines' Sarah Booth Delaney Mystery books would be my choice. All the titles have "Bones" in them. The first book was Them Bones. It is best to read them in order as these are on going stories. These books have a mystery, but the interatction between the characters brings me back to each new book. My favorite character is Jitty.

Sarah Booth Delaney, at last, home where she belongs. I enjoyed this quick new installment in this sassy Mississippi Delta series very much, although I wish I didn't find myself chastising my favorite heroines for being foolishly blind so often. She missed a couple of broad hints in this one. Aside from that, this was an unexpectedly moving chapter in her generally humorous life. Giant steps forward emotionally. I especially enjoyed watching her strong female friendships grow even deeper.

I just love this series and always look for the next one to come out. Sarah Booth is so cute yet feisty when need be. Jitty is always a great ghost of the house and so interesting. This time Sarah comes back to help her best friends husband try to recover from an illness no one knows the cause of but is tied to a house. Very funny at times and we see some sad times for Sarah as well. I loved it.

Greedy BonesI thoroughly enjoyed reading this book. I am from the south, not the Deep South, but southern enough to enjoy reading about it. I'm a country girl at heart and forever will be. Sarah Booth is spunky, funny and yet a true southern gal. With a twist of mystery added to the mix makes for a great read. Enjoy all the Caroline Haines books, they're well worth the time to read them!

This is my first book by Carolyn Haines. I really liked the characters and their relationship to each other, however I would have liked to have seen more of the spark between Sarah Booth and her love interest, Graf and her ex flame, Coleman. The plot was good, but sometimes a little confusing. The book as a whole was a bit wordy for me, and I found myself flash reading over parts that I thought were of no value. But all in all, I would try another book from this author.

The previous book was my least favorite in the series, and this one is my favorite to this point! The plot was more complicated than the others and there was more drama and suspense. This is the first book in the series where I haven't known the majority of the "whodunit" before the resolution. I liked seeing Sarah in a softer, more vulnerable state. This book made me excited to continue with the series.
